bibl.title: Letter from Willard L. Beaulac to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1952

div1.p: Beaulac, of the American Embassy in Havana, informs Hench that he will attend the dedication of Camp Lazear. He would be pleased to host a reception as well.

div1.head: Letter from Willard L. Beaulac to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1952

opener.dateline:
THE FOREIGN SERVICE
OF THE
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
Habana, November 24, 1952

div1.p:
I have not died since I had the pleasure of
seeing you in Habana last January, and if I survive
the traffic hazards here I hope and expect to be
with you at the ceremony on December 3. Also, I
shall be pleased to give a reception at the house
for the distinguished guests who will come here from
the United States and for such Cubans as you might
wish to suggest. I don't know yet, of course, what
the program is or whether there would be time for
that sort of thing; but I shall be glad to do whatever
I can along that line.

Thank you for the enclosures to your letter, all
of which are in the best style of Henry James and all
of which I have read with the greatest interest.

Louise and Gilbert Smith, who will probably be
out of the country at the time of the ceremony, have
asked me to remember them most kindly to you and Mrs.
Hench and to tell you how much they regret not being
able to be with you here.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Willard L. Beaulac Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
